SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER Experiences

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer diet
( ) Pioneer schools
( ) Pioneer churches
( ) Pioneer recreation and social life
( ) Pioneer farming experiences
( ) Folklore in Saskatchewan
( ) Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

A word of explanation to the person answering their questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as anyone else. Some of the questions have been asked so that they may apply to your experiences; others may not. The answers given will not be used in any publication or report.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1974, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: NORMAN SYLVESTER MAIR

2. Your address: PRINCE

3. Date: Feb 26, 1955

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): BYRON, ONT.

5. What was your father's name and occupation? ANDREW MAIR, FARMER

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): MAY 1903

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:
   KEWATON, ONT. SUMMER OF 1901

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.): 21 YEARS

9. What were your reasons for coming West? FATHER LOST 5 COWS & ONLY A SMALL FARM LEFT. FARMS WERE PRICED HIGH IN ONT.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?):

11. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? (Specify the name of the occupation):
    WORKED ON MY FATHER'S FARM BEFORE
PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is not advisable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: NORMAN RYLEYESTER MAIR
2. Your address: PRINCE
3. Date: Feb 26, 1953
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): BYERS, ONT.
5. What was your father's name and occupation? ANDREW MAIR, FARMER
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): MAY 1903
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan:
   (giving dates wherever possible):
   NEWTON, ONT. SUMMER 1901
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," etc.) I WAS IN MY TEENS, ETC., 21 YEARS
9. What were your reasons for coming West? (Father had a farm only in Ont.)
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   Very Venturesome.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   Travelled with a friend, picked up brother William at Rat Portage.

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   Train to Saskatoon then horse.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
   1/4 miles out of Saskatoon it started snowing until the ground was white.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   In a tent in Saskatoon.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   Township 46, Range 16, West 3rd PRINCE 1/4 mile north of Battleford.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
   None.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
   Worked on my Father's farm before & after.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? Very favorable.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other group)? Yes

13. What means of transportation did you use? Train to Saskatoon, then horse.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc. 1/4 mile out of Saskatoon, started snowing until the ground was white.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? In a tent in Saskatoon.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? Prince Albert, Saskatchewan.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. None.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came? Worked on my father's farm before I came.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   Not very often.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
    [Signature] March 28th 1912
    Meota, Sask.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?
    Yes.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.
    The family all came & settled in the same vicinity.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
    Made a trip to Saskatoon in March 1904 with oxen taking 21 days.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
    No.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Not very often.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

[Handwritten text]

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatoon because of your recommendation? It was a place to settle.

Yes.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.

The family all came, settled in Saskatoon.

23. In there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

Made a trip to Saskatoon in March 1904 without taking 21 days.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often?

No!
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   1910

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   Didn't own one.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Battleford 14 miles

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   Until the railroad came to North Battleford in 1905

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   Seldom

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   About the year 1912 there was a market in North Battleford where farmers sold their produce on Saturdays.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   We ordered from Eaton's as soon as they opened a mail order house in Winnipeg.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   Jan 1st 1916 - Glenrose Rural Telephone Co

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   With the idea of staying permanently
25. When was the first car used in the community? 1910

26. If you owned a car before 1911, when did you buy it? What makes?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)

29. How often did you shop in the early days?

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchase made by mail order since the pioneer period.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision? Will the idea stay permanently?
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving? Yes, some moved to town others left the locality.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return? No.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Secretary & Trustee of Scottygrass School District
Councillor of Rural Municipality of Meota 2 years
President of Telephone Club director 1911-1912
Ever since it was organized.
Director of North Battleford Agricultural Society for many years.
Director of Saskatchewan Dairy Association for 8 yrs (President for 1 year).

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

School District named after settlers.
Railway Station named after lake in vicinity.
Prince was named after Senator Prince of Battleford.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1942? What reasons did they have for moving?

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

36. If you or some member of your family have held public offices or been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Secretary, Board of Directors, North Battleford Chamber of Commerce

President, North Battleford Chamber of Commerce

Director, North Battleford Industrial Society

Director, North Battleford Dairy Association

37. If you or any of your family or friends were elected to have or do something in the interest of the community, give details whenever possible, such as owning the first automobile, company organizing the first lodge, etc.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School) districts, Post Offices, Villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc., try to give (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in name since the first name was given, data and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Battleford Station named after Lake previously called Prince Albert.

Prince Albert named after Senator Prince.
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

Would you or the person who owns them either

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon?

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

Hugh O'Alain Blair North (Battleford) works for wholesale grocer store.

Ina Gertrude Mais (now Coleman) housewife in Edmonton.

Ralph Mais (farming at home).

Norma Jean Mais (now Green) married & nursing in city hospital Saskatoon.

Grandchildren Elaine & Douglas Mais.

Bob & Norma Coleman.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

Roads come first.
